channel.title: Linux problem
channel.description: Where's the .minecraft folder at on linux? Ubuntu to be exact.

item.title: Linux problem
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Moparisthebest:

You can install a GUI in arch, and you can also remove the GUI from Ubuntu. Or just do Ctrl+Alt+F1 to switch to a virtual terminal.

Yeah. But there’s also some package issues I can’t fix with Arch(ie. wireless/ethernet drivers for my laptop). The drivers however come with the latest kernel, which Arch Linux hasn’t move up to yet…(last update was May last year >.>)

Read full topic

item.title: Linux problem
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

I actually accidentally installed plain ubuntu server on here (not a good idea if it’s your first linux!) but I soon realized it was only a few package installs in order to get a GUI

Read full topic

item.title: Linux problem
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:35, topic:388189”][quote author=zyle1992 link=topic=484006.msg3549510#msg3549510 date=1301422960]

And you can also install it directly on non-mac hardware to create a hackintosh. But I guarantee no super-computers run it.

Yup i did that once. It worked adequately, but there were many bugs with it. I just decided to remove it all together and use a tri-boot Ubuntu, Arch Linux and Windows.
[/quote]Why ubuntu and arch? At the moment I dual boot Ubuntu and Windows XP on this (though I never use the windows :P) and then I run Windows 7 on the computer in my room.[/quote]

I have UBuntu, Arch, And W7. The reason I use Ubuntu and Arch is because I like the simplicity of Arch Linux. No fancy GUIs, just pure CLI goodness

Read full topic

item.title: Linux problem
item.dc:creator: @B2300_T4nk B2300 T4nk
item.description:
@B2300_T4nk wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:11, topic:388189”][quote author=Pure season link=topic=484006.msg3546826#msg3546826 date=1301241620]
more then 75% of super computers are running linux or mac + linux combined
[/quote]

That’s not the statistic at all, also it would have to run mac OR linux, not both, and mac can’t be ran on super-computers at all because it can only be run on official Apple products.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linux#Servers.2C_mainframes_and_supercomputers:

Linux distributions are also commonly used as operating systems for supercomputers: since November 2010[update], out of the top 500 systems, 459 (91.8%) run a Linux distribution.[69] Linux was also selected as the operating system for the world’s most powerful supercomputer, IBM’s Sequoia which will become operational in 2011.[70]

Linux runs on everything from super-computers down to the tiniest little embedded device, like a toaster or microwave. And it’s awesome running on all of them. :)[/quote]Well Mac does work on Windows computers via VMWare.

Read full topic

item.title: Linux problem
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

[quote=“noobs are ftw, post:30, topic:388189”][quote author=CoonHunter link=topic=484006.msg3548301#msg3548301 date=1301337219]

Whoever said Windows costs less then Linux needs to check there facts more often. Linux is free. Whereas if you purchase a 1000 dollar laptop your probably paying 20 percent (200 dollars) for your copy of Windows.

I thought it was less than 20%

i just grew tight to windows xp never used anything else
maybe ill try linux

You should try ubuntu, im using that now and its 9999 times faster and better Although the compatibility with games and linux doesn’t fair too well

use wine for windows games and ur fine

I own 5 games that cannot run properly under wine.
[/quote]

sucks to be you they usualy work for me[/quote]
All depends on if the game works without special frameworks or anything. Generally I am under windows anyways unless I am going some programming, so its all good.

Read full topic

item.title: Linux problem
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“jmood128, post:15, topic:388189”][quote author=noobs are ftw link=topic=484006.msg3547639#msg3547639 date=1301274336]

more then 75% of super computers are running linux or mac + linux combined

That’s not the statistic at all, also it would have to run mac OR linux, not both, and mac can’t be ran on super-computers at all because it can only be run on official Apple products.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linux#Servers.2C_mainframes_and_supercomputers:

Linux distributions are also commonly used as operating systems for supercomputers: since November 2010[update], out of the top 500 systems, 459 (91.8%) run a Linux distribution.[69] Linux was also selected as the operating system for the world’s most powerful supercomputer, IBM’s Sequoia which will become operational in 2011.[70]

Linux runs on everything from super-computers down to the tiniest little embedded device, like a toaster or microwave. And it’s awesome running on all of them.

i seriously wonder why all the computers you see nowadays are windows lol

It’s because most computer company’s know that the common home user is going to use windows over Mac and Linux because for one Windows is cheaper then Mac and two Linux isn’t for the common home user…

i beg to differ lol look at ubuntu for example its linux for retards like me
[/quote]

You still need to know more then the common Windows user…[/quote]

That’s entirely wrong as well. Installing windows is much harder then installing something like Ubuntu, and after you install windows, you have to track down all the drivers for you hardware and install them, where as with Ubuntu, everything ‘just works’ most of the time. It also comes with everything the normal user would need, such as an Office Suite and a (good) browser. Windows isn’t nearly as user-friendly.

Read full topic

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linux#Servers.2C_mainframes_and_supercomputers:

Linux distributions are also commonly used as operating systems for supercomputers: since November 2010[update], out of the top 500 systems, 459 (91.8%) run a Linux distribution.[69] Linux was also selected as the operating system for the world’s most powerful supercomputer, IBM’s Sequoia which will become operational in 2011.[70]

Linux runs on everything from super-computers down to the tiniest little embedded device, like a toaster or microwave. And it’s awesome running on all of them.
